questions.question: Most computer instructions can be classified into three categories: Data transfer, Data manipulation, and Program control instructions.
Load instruction transfers data from a processor register to memory.
Store instruction transfers data from memory to a processor register.
Move instruction transfers data from one register to another register.
Exchange instruction is a type of Data Transfer Instruction.
Swap information can occur between two registers or a register and a memory word.
Input/Output operations transfer data among processor registers and input/output devices.
Push/Pop operations transfer data between processor registers and a memory stack.
The '@' symbol represents Immediate Mode in addressing.
The '$' symbol represents Address relative to PC in addressing.
The '#' symbol represents Indirect Address in addressing.
The '( )' symbols represent Index Mode, Register Indirect, Autoincrement in addressing.
Arithmetic Instructions are part of Data Transfer Instructions.
Program Control Instructions specify conditions for altering the content of PC.
The change in PC value as a result of the execution of a program control instruction causes a break in the sequence of instruction execution.
Branch and Jump instructions are used interchangeably to mean the same.
The bits in the status register are set or cleared based on operations performed in the ALU.
The status register is a 8-bit register.
Bit C (carry) is set to 1 if the end carry C8 is 1.
Bit S (sign) is set to 1 if F7 is 0.
Bit Z (zero) is set to 1 if the output of the ALU contains all 0â€™s.
Bit V (overflow) is set to 1 if the exclusive-OR of the last two carries (C8 and C7) is equal to 1.
In 2's complement representation, the binary number 11101100 represents a negative number.
The flags C = 1, S = 1, V = 0, Z = 0 indicate an overflow occurred during the last arithmetic operation.
Different computers always use the same temporary location to store the return address.
Using a stack memory to store the return address is the most efficient method.
During a subroutine call, the content of the PC is pushed onto the stack.
The stack pointer is incremented before popping the return address from the stack.
An interrupt transfers program control from a currently running program to another service program.
Control does not return to the original program after the service program is executed.
An interrupt is initiated by an internal or external signal.
A subroutine call is initiated by an internal or external signal.
A software interrupt is initiated by an external signal.
The address of the interrupt service program is determined by the hardware.
The address of the subroutine call is determined from the address field of an instruction.
An interrupt procedure stores only the program counter (Return address).
A subroutine call stores all the information necessary to define the state of the CPU.
The Program Status Word (PSW) is the collection of all status bit conditions in the CPU.
The PSW is stored in a general-purpose register.
Supervisor Mode is when the CPU is executing a program that is part of the operating system.
User Mode is when the CPU is executing a program that is part of the operating system.
External Interrupts come from I/O devices, timing devices, or power supply monitoring circuits.
Internal Interrupts are caused by external sources such as I/O devices.
Attempting to divide by zero is considered an invalid operation.
A stack overflow is a valid operation in computing.
Software interrupts are initiated by executing an instruction.
RISC stands for Reduced Instruction Set Computing.
CISC stands for Complex Instruction Set Computing.
The main difference between RISC and CISC is in the number of computing cycles each of their instructions take.
CISC instructions typically utilize fewer cycles than RISC instructions.
CISC has a larger, more feature-rich instruction set compared to RISC.
RISC processors generally have slower clock speeds than CISC processors.
RISC architectures typically have more general purpose registers than CISC.
CISC architecture typically has a large number of instructions ranging from 100 to 250.
CISC architecture does not include instructions that perform specialized tasks.
CISC architecture has a large variety of addressing modes, typically from 5 to 20 different modes.
CISC architecture uses fixed-length instruction formats.
Instructions in CISC architecture can manipulate operands in memory.
RISC architectures have a relatively large number of registers in the processor unit.
Memory access in RISC architectures is limited to load and store instructions.
All operations in RISC architectures are done within the registers of the CPU.
RISC architectures use microprogrammed control rather than hardwired control.
RISC architectures typically have a fixed-length, easily decoded instruction format.
RISC architectures support single-cycle instruction execution.
RISC architectures use overlapped register windows to speed up procedure call and return.
RISC architectures have a relatively large number of addressing modes.
Compiler support is essential for translating high-level language programs into machine language programs.
Overlapped Register Windows eliminate the need for saving and restoring register values.
Time-consuming operations during procedure calls are not related to saving and restoring registers.
Passing of parameters and results is not facilitated by Overlapped Register Windows.
The concept of overlapped register windows involves a total of 74 registers.
R0 - R9 are Global registers.
R10 - R63 are divided into 4 windows.
R26 - R31 store parameters and results for procedure B.
R16 - R25 are local to procedure B.
R32 - R41 are local to procedure A.
The circular window includes 10 Local registers.
Each window has 2 sets of 6 registers common to adjacent windows.
G represents Local registers in the organization of register windows.
L represents Local registers in the organization of register windows.
C represents Global registers in the organization of register windows.
The number of registers available for each window is calculated as Window Size = L + 2C + G.
The total number of registers needed in the processor is calculated as Register file = (L + C) * W + G.
The formula for Window Size includes the term 3C.
The formula for Register File includes the term (L + C) * W - G.
